title: 108_s436
content: The Act titled "Domestic Surveillance Oversight Act of 2003" improves the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to allow FISA courts to establish rules and procedures necessary for their responsibilities, which must be recorded and transmitted to specific entities. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to include reporting requirements for specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. Title VI of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 includes a public reporting requirement by the Attorney General. Title VI of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 mandates the Attorney General to issue an annual public report detailing the number of U.S. persons targeted for surveillance orders under various sections of the Act, the authorization of information use in criminal proceedings, and the completion of statements. The Attorney General is required to issue an annual public report under Title VI of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978, detailing the completion of statements accompanying information disclosures for law enforcement purposes and redacting sensitive information related to national security in court documents and orders. The courts established under section 103 must provide significant construction or interpretation of the provisions of the Act or the US Constitution in their reports. The table of contents for the Act is amended to include new items related to Title VI. Title VI requires public reporting by the Attorney General, while Title VII specifies the effective date. Section 3 introduces additional improvements for congressional oversight of surveillance activities. The amendments to Title 18, United States Code and the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978 require the Attorney General to provide detailed reports to congressional committees on requests made for information from public libraries and financial institutions. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include the Committee on Financial Services and the Committee on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives. The term 'congressional intelligence committees' is defined in the National Security Act of 1947. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs, and the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate.
